extendedIngredients.name: chicken
extendedIngredients.original: 1 whole pasture-raised stewing chicken (about 3 to 4 pounds)

extendedIngredients.name: fresh chives
extendedIngredients.original: minced fresh chives or parsley (to serve)
extendedIngredients.originalName: minced fresh chives or parsley (to serve)

extendedIngredients.name: heavy cream
extendedIngredients.original: 2 cups heavy cream (preferably raw, not ultra-pasteurized)

title: a vintage : cream of chicken soup
summary: You can never have too many main course recipes, so give a vintage : cream of chicken soup a try. This recipe serves 8. One serving contains 666 calories, 36g of protein, and 54g of fat. For $1.92 per serving, this recipe covers 23% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. It will be a hit at your Autumn event. It is a good option if you're following a gluten free and primal diet. Only a few people made this recipe, and 1 would say it hit the spot. If you have unrefined sea salt, onion, heavy cream, and a few other ingredients on hand, you can make it. To use up the butter you could follow this main course with the Cinnamon Butter Cake as a dessert. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes roughly 45 minutes. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 40%. This score is pretty good. Try Vintage vanilla fudge, Panzerotti: Vintage Swap, and Vintage chocolate chip cookies for similar recipes.
instructions: Rinse the chicken thoroughly and pat it dry before placing it in your stock pot, covering it completely with fresh, clean and very cold water (about one and one-half gallons).Stud the leek with whole cloves, and place it in the stock pot along side the stewing chicken.  Add the celery leaves, onion top and carrot tops to the water.Slowly simmer the clove-studded leek, celery leaves, onion top and carrot tops in the water, uncovered, until the chicken is completely cooked and tender to the bone, about two hours.Once the chicken is tender, remove it from the the stockpot and allow it to cool.  Remove the bay leaves, celery leaves, onion top and carrot tops from the broth, straining it if necessary.  Discard the vegetable matter, but continue simmering the broth, uncovered, while you prepare the remaining ingredients.As the chicken cools, prepare the vegetables by peeling and mincing the carrots and mincing the onion and celery stalks as well.Melt the butter in a cast iron skillet until it foams, and toss the minced vegetables into the pan.  Fry the vegetables in butter until they become fragrant and tender, about five minutes.  Remove them from the heat and allow them to cool.Once the chicken has cooled, remove its meat, saving the bones to roast for another round of stock.Place the chicken meat and cooled vegetables into a food processor and pulse until theyâ€™re finely ground.  If you have no food processor, you can mince the chicken and vegetables finely.Stir the vegetables and chicken meat back into the simmering broth and turn off the stove.Temper the beaten eggs by stirring a spoonful of broth into the eggs, then pouring the mixture of eggs and broth into the simmering soup.Gently stir two cups of heavy cream into the broth and serve, dressed with minced fresh herbs and seasoned with unrefined sea salt.

steps.step: Rinse the chicken thoroughly and pat it dry before placing it in your stock pot, covering it completely with fresh, clean and very cold water (about one and one-half gallons).Stud the leek with whole cloves, and place it in the stock pot along side the stewing chicken.

Add the celery leaves, onion top and carrot tops to the water.Slowly simmer the clove-studded leek, celery leaves, onion top and carrot tops in the water, uncovered, until the chicken is completely cooked and tender to the bone, about two hours.Once the chicken is tender, remove it from the the stockpot and allow it to cool.

Remove the bay leaves, celery leaves, onion top and carrot tops from the broth, straining it if necessary.  Discard the vegetable matter, but continue simmering the broth, uncovered, while you prepare the remaining ingredients.As the chicken cools, prepare the vegetables by peeling and mincing the carrots and mincing the onion and celery stalks as well.Melt the butter in a cast iron skillet until it foams, and toss the minced vegetables into the pan.  Fry the vegetables in butter until they become fragrant and tender, about five minutes.
Remove them from the heat and allow them to cool.Once the chicken has cooled, remove its meat, saving the bones to roast for another round of stock.

Place the chicken meat and cooled vegetables into a food processor and pulse until theyâ€™re finely ground.  If you have no food processor, you can mince the chicken and vegetables finely.Stir the vegetables and chicken meat back into the simmering broth and turn off the stove.Temper the beaten eggs by stirring a spoonful of broth into the eggs, then pouring the mixture of eggs and broth into the simmering soup.Gently stir two cups of heavy cream into the broth and serve, dressed with minced fresh herbs and seasoned with unrefined sea salt.
